Furthermore, in view of the fact it is unmistakably disclosed by the evidence many of the appellant’s buildings, apartments and flats are vacant, and that there is much other similar unrented property in Chicago, and that tenants have only been secured for many of his other buildings by great reductions in rental prices and donations of rents for short periods, and other expedients, it would, be manifestly unjustifiable to estimate the income of the appellant upon the theory that it might be made larger than it is by the construction of still more buildings, apartments and flats. The demand is not for more tenements, but for more tenants to occupy buildings, rooms and apartments already constructed and standing vacant and unoccupied. We are concerned with the actual and real situation, and not with mere theories and enthusiastic anticipations. As illustrative of the effort to overcome the facts and details appearing in the proof relative to the income-producing value of appellant’s property by wholly insignificant circumstances, we may instance the following suggestion of counsel for appellee in their brief: “That his income was $100,000 per year is a fair inference from a letter” written by a relative, “wherein he refers to him (appellant) argumentatively as a man with an income of $100,000 per year.” It appeared the conclusion reached by the master, based upon the prospective potential or anticipated income of the appellant, was that the appellee should be awarded permanent alimony in the sum of $5000 per year, and that counsel for appellee insisted that the bad conduct or delictum of the appellant should operate to increase her allowance, and that, after hearing argument upon the question, he adopted the views so urged by counsel for appellee and added $3000 per annum to the amount previously determined upon by him, and recommended the sum of *$8000 per annum be decreed to be paid to appellee, $3000 thereof being awarded “on account of the delictum of the defendant” (appellant). The chancellor, upon consideration of the master’s report, reduced the proposed permanent annual alimony to $6400.

The situation, as we believe it to be from the vast mass of testimony touching upon the point, is, that the appellant was in the more prosperous former years in the enjoyment of a net income of from $50,000 to $75,000 per year during different years; that the property which produced that income has depreciated very greatly in its real value, and still more largely in its salable value and income-producing capacity; that his indebtedness has grown larger in its actual sum, and very much larger in comparison with" his ability to discharge it out of the property mortgaged to secure it, or to pay interest upon it from the income of his property; that other investments have proved unprofitable and increased his actual indebtedness and involved him in litigation as to other large demands as surety; that he is threatened with foreclosure of mortgages against his property and sales thereunder; that he is burdened with interest demanded annually in a large sum in the aggregate, and called upon to pay heavy charges for repairs of his buildings, which increase yearly as the buildings grow older, and that his gross income has been materially reduced and his net income still more decreased in proportion; that judgments at law against him are unpaid and that he is unable to meet many demands admittedly just and due, and that his belief is justified that it is only by the exercise of economy, sound judgment and dilig'ent attention in the manag'ement of his property and his affairs that he may avert financial ruin and extricate some fair proportion of his estate from that which threatens to absorb it all. The testimony of the appellee with relation to the manner in which payments of temporary alimony have been made to her, and the course pursued by her in endeavoring to collect and secure payment of the numerous small checks received from appellant; the fact she claims large arrearages of preliminary alimony are unpaid, and that by reason of the default in such payment she has been required to devote her own means to her support, and yet did not seek to enforce payment by attachment for contempt for a number of years, is consistent with the view the appellant has been and is in financial distress and pressed to secure ready money to meet demands against him, and that appellee knew such to be the real situation of his' affairs. Though living separate and apart from him, the appellee retains the legal rights and interests, present and prospective, of a wife in his property. Her interest is allied with his in everything that tends to rescue his property from the dangers with which it is now encompassed. A just and proper determination of his abilities and faculties is a matter not only of present but of future concern and importance to her. His success in the struggle to save his estate is her reliance for the payment of whatever may be awarded her for alimony and also as to her prospective interest in his property.

Our statute expressly requires that permanent alimony shall be determined with reference to the condition of the parties in life and the circumstances of the respective cases. (Hurd’s Stat. 1897, par. 22, chap. 69, entitled “Husband and Wife.”) The faculties of the husband; the property, and ability of the husband to pay the amount awarded; the income of both the husband and wife, and from what source the wealth came; the age and ability of each; the conduct of the one who has offended—and of both the parties, for that matter; the nature of the situation of the estate of the husband and the amount which the condition of the affairs of the husband will enable him to pay without impairing his business, may be considered by the court. (1 Am. & Eng. Ency. of Law, 480, 481.) Alimony will be granted in proportion to the wants of the wife and the circumstances of the husband who is to pay it. (Foote v. Foote, 22 Ill. 425.) It is undoubtedly the rule, where there is no income and the payment of the allowance will diminish the estate from which the income is derived it will not ordinarily be permitted to extend beyond providing for the actual wants and necessities of the wife. (Harding v. Harding, 144 Ill. 588.) Where alimony is granted without a divorce, it may be increased or diminished by subsequent decree, if a change in the circumstances of the parties warrants such course, (Cole v. Cole, 142 Ill. 19; 1 Am. & Eng. Ency. of Law, 481;) and our statute expressly authorizes such subsequent chang'es in case of divorce. (Chap. 40, sec. 18.) The effect of the allowance upon the business affairs of the husband may be of the utmost importance, not only to the husband, but, in view of the fact the allowance to be fixed may be changed if the financial condition of the husband improves, the appellee is interested in all that favorably or unfavorably affects his estate.

The appellee was allowed $300 per month temporary alimony by a decree entered July 1, 1890. She has not sought to have the allowance increased, and seems to have fully recognized that it was not infrequently quite difficult for the appellant to provide that sum. In passing on an application of appellee to enforce payment of this alimony the court found he had paid something more than $13,000 as temporary alimony and was still liable to pay appellee $11,716 under the order of July 1, 1890, and entered a decree requiring, payment of the latter sum to be made. This decree is before us in conjunction with this cause, and has been found to be correct and will be affirmed in a separate opinion. The chancellor in the cause decreed the mother was entitled to the custody of the daughters from the date of filing the bill until they arrived at age, respectively, and decreed the appellant should pay appellee $8156.61 to reimburse to her the amounts expended by her in the past support of said daughters. This finding and decree we have herein affirmed. Appellant contends appellee, when she filed the bill, had possession of from $20,000 to $30,000 which she obtained from him. The exact amount may be questioned, but that all amounts expended by her in supporting the children were obtained by appellee from her husband cannot be doubted. He will therefore be required by this decree and the decree in the other cause to pay her, in the way of balance of temporary alimony unpaid and to reimburse her for expenditures for the daughters, in the aggregate more than $19,000. Her indebtedness, as we gather it from her testimony, does not exceed $1500. The payment of these large sums so awarded to the appellee will add to the already heavy financial burdens of the appellant and swell the sum of an indebtedness now alarmingly great. A thorough investigation of all the facts disclosed by the record, and much reflection thereon, impels us to the conclusion an allowance of the additional sum of $6400 per annum as alimony for the appellee is not justified by the present value and net income-producing capacity of the estate of the appellant, is not necessary for the reasonable support and maintenance of the appellee, and ought not, at least for the present, be required to be paid by the appellant. Future developments may make such sum, or even a larger amount, reasonable and proper, and if so, power rests in the court to increase the allowance. The appellee was granted $300 per month as temporary alimony when the value of the estate and the annual income thereof were much greater than now, and it does not appear she has complained that that sum was insufficient. We think, in view of all that has been said, no more than that amount should have been required by the chancellor to be paid by the appellant.

The decree in this respect will be modified by reducing the amount to be paid the appellee, until the further order of the court, to the sum of $3600 per annum, to be paid in monthly installments of $300. It is also ordered the decree to be rendered in pursuance of this opinion shall provide that such alteration in the allowance for alimony may be made by future decree or decrees as shall or may be found to be just and reasonable. The costs in this court will be paid by the appellant.

The decree of the circuit court and the judgment of the Appellate Court are affirmed except as herein ordered, and in that respect are reversed. The cause will be remanded to the circuit court, with directions to enter a decree in conformity with this opinion.

Affirmed in part and remanded.

 Mr. Justice Magruder,

dissenting:

I think that the judgment of the Appellate Court ought to be affirmed as to the allowance of $6400 for alimony, as well as in the other particulars mentioned; and upon this subject I refer to and adopt the following views of the Appellate Court as expressed in paragraph 11 of its opinion, which is omitted from the opinion as above quoted:

“Eleventh—A full and careful consideration of the evidence bearing upon the amount of appellant’s property, his income therefrom, his circumstances and situation generally, the appellee’s separate property, social position, health and circumstances, the g'eneral family history and manner of life of the parties prior to and since their separation, aside from the delictum of appellant as disclosed by the evidence, has led us to the conclusion that the decree of the chancellor in awarding appellee $6400 per annum as permanent alimony should not be reversed. The evidence is conflicting in many respects, and we are unable to say that the finding of the chancellor is manifestly wrong. The court saw many of the witnesses on the trial, and his findings should not be disturbed unless they are clearly and manifestly against the evidence. Delaney v. Delaney, 175 Ill. 187.

“This principle may also be properly applied to all the other issues in the case on which the evidence is conflicting. Anything like a comprehensive review of the evidence bearing on this finding would require an enormous amount of labor, which could prove of little or no benefit. It seems sufficient to say that, in our opinion, the chancellor would have been justified in finding from it that at the time of the hearing, in January and February, 1897, appellant was worth, over and above all his debts, an amount not less than $500,000, or even $1,000,000, and that he had a gross annual income from his property of at least $80,000 and a net income of $15,000 annually. A very important consideration in this regard is the fact that while appellant insisted that at the time of the hearing before the master in 1897 he had no net income, he declined to produce his books of account for examination. Also, in this connection, as well as with reference to all other matters in which the weight of appellant’s testimony is important, it may not be amiss to consider the fact, which appears from the record in case No. 7765 of this court, between the same parties, which was by agreement heard with this casé and in which the record in this case was to be considered so far as material, that appellant, on August 31, 1897, filed a bill for divorce, sworn to by him, against appellee, in the superior court of the county of SanDiego, in the State of California, in which he alleges, among other things, that in the month of February, 1890, appellee willfully and without just cause deserted and abandoned him, and ever since has been and still continues so to willfully and without just cause desert and abandon him and to live separate and apart from him without any sufficient cause or reason. This sworn statement of appellant, when considered in connection with appellant’s stipulation and the evidence in the case, we think tends strongly to support the conclusions of the master and the court; but it is unnecessary to, and we do not, base our conclusions in affirming" the circuit court upon this statement, since it was made after the decree in this cause. If the matter of appellant’s delictum were to be considered, which we have seen was an entirely proper matter for consideration, then there is a much stronger basis of support for the decree in this respect. The master considered appellant’s delictum (both cruelty and adultery) in arriving at his conclusions, but the chancellor has certified that he did not consider or pass upon the question of adultery, because he regarded it as unnecessary in view of appellant’s stipulation of January 3, 1893, although the master found facts which practically show that appellant was guilty of cruelty to appellee as well as of adultery with Mrs. A. R. Louis, and the decree approves the master’s finding's except as to the amount of alimony and the amount of the allowance for the minor children.

“It is contended by appellant that the proof did not sustain the findings of the master; that it failed to show appellant was guilty of adultery with Mrs. Louis, and, therefore, for this reason it could not form an element in fixing the amount of appellee’s alimony. However this contention may be as to the adultery, which we do not decide because the chancellor did not, the fact remains that appellee, upon appellant’s admission in open court, lived separate and apart from appellant without her fault. This can on this record only be referred to appellant’s cruelty, if he was not guilty of adultery, and that must have been the conclusion of the chancellor.”
